speaker: Amit Varma
message: There is only one thing political parties care about in a democracy, winning elections. This includes political parties out of power and those in power. You might assume that once a party wins elections and forms a government, its main focus is to govern responsibly. Well, LOL. In fact, ROTFLOL. All they care about is winning the next elections and there is very little correlation between governing well and getting votes. That's the nature of the beast.

speaker: Unknown
message: Welcome to The Seen and the Unseen, our weekly podcast on economics, politics and behavioral science. Please welcome your host, Amit Badma.

message: Welcome to The Seen and the Unseen. A few weeks ago, in the magazine I edit, Pragati, at ThinkPragati.com, I reviewed an excellent book called How the BJP Wins by Prashant Jha. Now, no matter what you think of the BJP or Narendra Modi, and my opposition to the man in the party is well known, everyone agrees that the election machine is just stupendous. In fact, reading the book brought me round to the view that given the complexity of the Indian political marketplace, Amit Shah might even be the greatest political strategist in history. So my guest today on the show is the author of that fine book, Prashant Jha. Prashant works at the Hindustan Times and I caught up with him a few weeks ago at the sidelines of the Bangalore Literature Festival. Here's a conversation we had. Prashant, welcome to The Seen and the Unseen. Thank you, Amit, for having me. Prashant, your book How the BJP Wins was a great eye-opener for me because I had been led to some much simpler notions of why the BJP did what they did. One partly assumed that, hey, people were sick of the previous UPA government and so on. There was a development narrative. There was a RSS polarization narrative and there were these simple narratives and one assumed that everything just came together and I'd written in the past that Modi was like a Rorschach inkblot, test people could see in him what they wanted. speaker: Unknown
message: it ought to be sort of a case study. So when we start, what are the sort of separate elements you break this down into?

speaker: Guest
message: What did they start off by thinking about when they started planning the 2014 campaign? I think it's something useful to always think about when we're thinking about elections that it's always easier to understand elections in retrospect and when election campaigning is on, when these strategies are being formulated, it's more difficult to grasp it. So looking back, what we can see now is that the one dominant strand in the BJP strategy was projection of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's image and image is quite central to it. I spoke to Govind Acharya, one of the older Sangh ideologues who used to play an important role in the BJP, and he said to me, for Narendra Modi, politics is equal to power, power stems from elections, elections are about images and so politics is equal to images signalling and messaging. And if you use that framework to understand Modi, what you see is that between 2002 and 2007, Modi was a Hindu Hriday Samrat based on what had happened in Gujarat. From 2007, there was a conscious imagery invention of becoming a Vikas Purush delivering a Gujarat model of development, while retaining elements of the strong Hindu Hriday image. But over the past two, two and a half years, it is these twin images that had come in the 2014 election. He felt the need for it when he had to backtrack on amending the Land Acquisition Act. He felt the need for it when he started being mocked for his foreign travels. He felt the need for it after Rahul Gandhi made what clearly has been the sharpest political intervention yet of a suit boot ki sarkar. And BJP felt that its problem, its handicap throughout was that it was seen as a party of urban India, as a party of a sliced middle class, as a party which was soft towards the elites. And Modi decided that that's not the image trap that he wanted to remain with. And so we see this reinvention happening, and that reinvention took two forms. The first was a narrative around demonetization. You have written, Amit, about demonetization, and we now clearly know that the economics of demonetization was all flawed. speaker: Unknown

message: If one was to identify key elements in it, the first, when he took over as president, was focusing on numbers and the quantitative expansion of the membership base. speaker: Unknown
message: got no votes. And they said, these are Muslim booths, we won't worry about them.

speaker: Guest
message: The other booths, they told these booth committees that, look, we want you to enroll 100 members each in your booths. Now, usually what happens in political parties is that between elections, booth committees are dormant. Now here, the booth committees have just worked and delivered your 2014 mandate, and the party headquarter was telling the party booth committee, no, go back and get us 100 members each. Then they told the new members, get us more members. They recognize that a state like UP or even Bihar has high degrees of intrastate migration. We think about these states contributing migrant labor to Bombay, to Delhi, but there's high levels of intrastate migration because women marry and move to other villages. So they set up block level camps so that women or even men who migrated for work would get an opportunity to enroll themselves as members. So there is this quantitative expansion. The second was that in this process, what they were also doing was qualitatively changing the nature of the relationship between the party high command and the party grassroots. So there were 60 to 80 seats in UP where they were not winning. What did they do?
